entry.headline: Weak dollar, strong consumer seen good for Disney
entry.body:
LOS ANGELES (Reuters) - A weak dollar, confident consumers and a new television ratings system could buttress Walt Disney Co's (DIS.N) performance this year, analysts said ahead of the company's third quarter results announcement on Wednesday.

Most analysts expect Disney's broadcast and cable business, the largest contributor to revenue and operating income, to fuel a fifth straight year of double-digit growth in operating income, and for its theme parks to contribute at least modestly to the bottom line.

Analysts, on average, expect net earnings of 56 cents per share and revenue of $9.04 billion for the quarter, according to Reuters Estimates.

The weak dollar could be attracting greater numbers of European travelers to Walt Disney World Resort, which generates about 80 percent of the theme parks division's revenue and operating income, said SMH Capital analyst David Miller.

"I would say that folks are going to be pleasantly surprised by the performance of parks in the June quarter," Miller said. "It wouldn't surprise us to see Disney clock in with mid-single digit revenue growth at the parks."

Analysts expect big things from Disney Consumer Products, its smallest business, which said earlier this year it would see record-breaking global retail sales of $26 billion in fiscal 2007. Disney receives royalties and other revenue equal to a low double-digit percentage of retail sales.

"This segment should be up nicely," Bank of America analyst Jonathan Jacoby said in a note to clients.

Despite generally upbeat expectations for fiscal 2007, which ends September 30, some, including UBS analyst Michael Morris, cautioned Disney was "highly exposed" to risk from a slowing economy or consumer weakness.

Miller also said three of the company's business were "highly tethered to the economy."

"The stock price could be affected by any measurable economic downturn ... but aside from housing, the economy is good," he said.

Data released on Tuesday by the Confidence Board showed U.S. consumer confidence in July rising to a near-six-year high and that most U.S. consumers expect business conditions, income and employment to remain the same in the next six months.

For the third quarter, Walt Disney Studios faces tough comparisons with last year, which included the top-selling DVD release of "The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe." But the studio's performance should benefit later this year when their costs are accounted for, from "Ratatouille" and the third "Pirates of the Caribbean," and on lower costs from a smaller film slate.

The two films, released in May and June, have racked up $1.16 billion so far at global box offices and are expected to be released on DVD in Disney's fiscal 2008 first quarter.

Analysts said the ABC network could enjoy momentum in the quarter and back half of the year from hit shows such as "Grey's Anatomy" and "Ugly Betty," which continue to deliver strong advertising and syndication revenues.

The cable networks, especially ESPN and the Disney Channel, were seen as strong drivers of affiliate fees and subscriber growth, with ESPN delivering deferred revenue in the quarter.

Disney's TV business could see an upside starting this fall from political advertising and from a new audience measuring system that counts viewers who record shows and watch them later.

Lehman Bros. analyst Anthony DiClemente said Disney appears to have benefited from the new ratings system, which pushed up prices during this year's advance advertising sales.

entry.headline: UPDATE 2-MOVES-Marsh, Lehman, JPMorgan Hedge Fund
entry.body:
(Adds Marsh Inc, others)

July 31 (Reuters) - The following financial service industry appointments were announced on Tuesday. To inform us of other job changes, please e-mail moves@reuters.com.

MARSH INC

The insurance broker and business risk advisor said Mark Feuer added the role of chief executive of the U.S. business to his existing responsibilities. Feuer will continue to lead Marsh's U.S. middle market and small commercial segments and will remain a member of the firm's executive committee. Feuer joined Marsh in November 2006, the company said. Marsh is a unit of Marsh McLennan Cos Inc (MMC.N).

LEHMAN BROTHERS HOLDINGS INC LEH.N

The investment bank said it hired a team of investment bankers from Rio Bravo, a leading Brazilian investment banking advisory firm and a diversified alternative investment manager. Winston Fritsch, formerly the head of Rio Bravo's corporate origination and corporate finance team, was named a managing director and head of Lehman Brothers investment banking in Brazil. Eduardo Langoni and Peter Tilley also joined as senior vice presidents, reporting to Fritsch.

GENERAL ELECTRIC (GE.N)

GE Commercial Finance Corporate Lending today named James Hallock managing director of the restructuring finance team, with responsibility for providing turnaround finance to mid-size and large companies throughout the northeastern United States. He previously managed debtor-in-possession financing in the distressed assets group at Credit Agricole's Calyon Corporate and Investment Bank.

HARRIS WILLIAMS CO

Harris Williams, a unit of PNC Financial Services Group Inc (PNC.N), said it promoted seven professionals from the firm's Richmond office. Bob Baltimore, James Clark, Derek Lewis and Drew Spitzer have been promoted to director, and David Keys, Brian Lucas and Geoff Smith have been promoted to vice president.

JPMORGAN CHASE CO (JPM.N)

JPMorgan Hedge Fund Services said it named Andrew Mascall-Robson to lead business development and growth across Asia and Shirley Yuen as regional product and client service manager. Mascall-Robson and Yuen join JPMorgan from Fortis Prime Fund Solutions, JPMorgan said.

CREDIT SUISSE (CSGN.VX)

Credit Suisse said it appointed Connie Holden to its UK Institutional Distribution team in asset management. Holden who was previously at JP Morgan Securities Services, will be based in London.

CLARIFI

The Standard Poor's Capital IQ business and leading provider of software and services focused on quantitative portfolio management and research, appointed Andrew Hicks to their Business Development team. Hicks will be based in the London office and previously worked with UBS.

LONDON CAPITAL

The fund manager said it appointed Alison Yard as head of real estate funds. Yard joined from Arlington Property Investors.

London Capital also appointed Robin Matthews as acquisitions manager. He was previously at Colliers CRE.

Hubertus Baumer was appointed as assistant German real estate fund manager. He was previously at DTZ Consulting. The three will be based in the company's London headquarters.

HALLIWELLS LLP

The UK based multi-disciplinary law firm appointed Michael McCarthy with the London Corporate Recovery team as a partner. He was earlier at Reed Smith Richards Butler.

DEBEVOISE PLIMPTON LLP

The international law firm announced that Anthony McWhirter will join its London office in September as a partner in the firm's investment management practice. McWhirter was previously a partner with Freshfields Bruckhaus Deringer.

HENDERSON GLOBAL INVESTORS

The independent asset manager appointed Jerome Sebaux as head of Property Finance. He will be based in Henderson's Paris office. Sebaux was previously at ING Real Estate Investment Management in France.

INVESTIT

The London based investment management consultancy appointed Alex Hindoian to its rapidly growing recruitment business, Investit People, as a senior recruitment specialist. Alex previously worked in the London office of Constantin Control Associates - an international management consulting and recruitment business.

INERV

The Amsterdam based European Association for Investors in Non-Listed Real Estate Vehicles (INREV) named Urban Land Institute executive and real estate journalist Andrea Carpenter as director research and market information, effective Aug. 1. (Compiled by Nachiket Kelkar in Bangalore)

entry.headline: Goldman set to beat Merrill in Italy property fund
entry.body:
MILAN, July 31 (Reuters) - Goldman Sachs (GS.N) is poised to win a war with Merrill Lynch MER.N for an Italian real estate fund after its higher offer, valuing the fund around 548 million euros ($750.9 million), won the favour of the fund's manager.

Goldman's final offer for 95 percent of the Berenice fund QFBER.MI, or 570,000 units, stood at 913 euros per unit against Merrill's 827 euros.

The fund's manager, Pirelli C Real Estate (PCRE.MI), recommended on Tuesday that Berenice unit holders accept Goldman's offer.

It said the offer was 19.8 percent higher than the fund's net asset value on June 30. It was also 40 percent higher than Goldman's initial offer of 650 euros, it said.

Pirelli RE, a real estate company controlled by Pirelli C (PECI.MI), said it had suspended the sale of five properties in Rome owned by the fund, as requested by Goldman.

Berenice owns 51 properties with a combined market value of about 845.4 million euros as at June 30, it said. Most are office buildings in Rome and Milan.

Goldman made the offer through a vehicle called Zwinger, while Merrill did it through its Galante vehicle.
